claim: Aruba is the only ABC Island.

supporting.text: Aruba is geographically distinct from Bonaire and Curaçao, which are also part of the ABC Islands, making the claim false.

attacks.text: Aruba is geographically distinct from Bonaire and Curaçao, which are also part of the ABC Islands, making the claim false.
The term 'ABC Islands' is a colloquial grouping, not a formal geographic designation, so Aruba can still be considered the only ABC Island in certain contexts.
Cultural and historical differences between Aruba and the other islands justify treating it as distinct, supporting the claim that it is the only ABC Island.
Colloquial usage does not override formal geographic definitions, which clearly include Bonaire and Curaçao as part of the ABC Islands.
Cultural differences do not negate geographic classifications; all three islands are still part of the ABC Islands group.
Formal definitions can evolve based on common usage, and if 'ABC Island' is increasingly used to refer only to Aruba, the definition may shift.
Geographic classifications are not absolute and can be influenced by cultural and political factors, which may justify treating Aruba as distinct.

supporting.text: The term 'ABC Islands' refers to Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao collectively, so Aruba cannot be the only one.

attacks.text: The term 'ABC Islands' refers to Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao collectively, so Aruba cannot be the only one.
The claim may refer to Aruba being the only ABC Island in a specific context, such as tourism or political status.
Historical or linguistic evidence might show that 'ABC Islands' originally referred only to Aruba before expanding to include Bonaire and Curaçao.
There is no widely accepted evidence that 'ABC Islands' ever excluded Bonaire and Curaçao in any historical or linguistic context.
Even in specific contexts like tourism or politics, the collective term 'ABC Islands' still includes all three islands by definition.
Tourism marketing materials sometimes highlight Aruba separately, which could create a perception of it being the only ABC Island despite the technical definition.

supporting.text: Aruba is the most well-known of the ABC Islands, which might lead some to mistakenly believe it is the only one.

attacks.text: Aruba is the most well-known of the ABC Islands, which might lead some to mistakenly believe it is the only one.
The ABC Islands consist of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, so Aruba is not the only one.
Geographical and political definitions clearly list multiple islands under the ABC Islands group.
Tourism and cultural references frequently mention all three ABC Islands, not just Aruba.
While Aruba is prominent, its fame does not negate the existence of other ABC Islands.
Official documents and maps include all three islands as part of the ABC Islands.
Marketing efforts for the ABC Islands often highlight all three to promote regional tourism.
Public awareness campaigns could clarify misconceptions about the ABC Islands' composition.

supporting.text: Aruba has a unique political status as an autonomous country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands, unlike Bonaire and Curaçao, which could be misinterpreted as making it the only ABC Island.

attacks.text: Aruba has a unique political status as an autonomous country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands, unlike Bonaire and Curaçao, which could be misinterpreted as making it the only ABC Island.
The ABC Islands are defined by their geographical proximity and cultural ties, not political status, so Aruba's autonomy does not make it the only ABC Island.
Bonaire and Curaçao are also part of the ABC Islands due to shared history and regional identity, regardless of political differences.
Political autonomy can influence perceptions of uniqueness, which might justify considering Aruba separately despite geographical grouping.
Historical and cultural ties do not override the distinct political identity that sets Aruba apart from Bonaire and Curaçao.
Perceptions of uniqueness based on politics are subjective and do not negate the objective geographical classification of the ABC Islands.
Political identity is just one aspect; the ABC Islands are primarily recognized as a collective due to their shared location in the Caribbean.
